Column Comment.0: ANALYSIS IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a sample analysis. Various types ofanalysis may be conducted on a sample. Samples may be derived from lithologiccuttings, fluid collection etc.
Column Comment.1: ANALYSIS SOURCE: The source that the analysis came from, this could be a labtechnician, a lab, a company, a government agency, etc.
Column Comment.2: ANALYSIS OBSERVATION NUMBER: A Unique observation number for the gaschromatography analysis.
Column Comment.3: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y or N flag indicating whether this row of data is currentlyeither active/valid (Y) or inactive/invalid (N).
Column Comment.4: ANALYSIS VALUE: The value of the analysis, this allows for a wide variety ofmeasures to be stored and the type of value will vary pending on the columnANALYSIS_VALUE_TYPE.
Column Comment.5: ANALYSIS VALUE CODE: a codified or text value, selected from a reference list,indicating the value of a measurement for gas chromatography. This column shouldnot be used for numeric or measured values, use ANL_VALUE for these.
Column Comment.7: ANALYSIS VALUE REMARK: A narrative remark about the analysis of the value.
Column Comment.8: ANALYSIS VALUE TYPE: Use this column to list the type of values for the analysis,in cases where the value is text based.
Column Comment.10: CALCULATED INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating that this value was calculated.
Column Comment.11: CALCULATION METHOD IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the method or formulaused to create a calculated or derived value..
Column Comment.12: DAUGHTER ION IDENTIFIER: A unique identifier for the daughter ion in the gaschromatography analysis. The daughter ion is an electrically charged ion that is thedirect product of a parent ion.
Column Comment.13: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.14: ERROR BAR VALUE: The value of the error bar in the value resulting from the gaschromatogram or some calculation on the information from the chromatogram. Thiswill aid in the analysis of the chromatogram.
Column Comment.17: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.18: GAS ANALYSIS VALUE TYPE: Use this column to list the type of values for the gaschromatography, in cases where the value is text based.
Column Comment.19: ANALYSIS MEASUREMENT TYPE: A list of valid measurement types. ANL QCVALID MEASURE lists which measurement types are valid for various types ofanalysis, and what valid ranges for the values should be. In analysis detail tables,ensure that you have selected a measurement type that is appropriate for the type ofstudy.
Column Comment.20: PARENT ION IDENTIFIER: A unique identifier for the parent ion in the gaschromatography analysis. The parent ion is a fragment of ions both charged andneutral that forms due to the dissociation of an electrically charged molecule and notdue to a reaction.
Column Comment.21: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.22: PREFERRED INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not gas chromatographyis the preferred method for the sample analysis.
Column Comment.23: PROBLEM INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not there is a problem withthe step. If a yes flag is indicated, additional information regarding the problemshould be noted in the table ANL_PROBLEM.
Column Comment.24: QUALIFIER ION: Use this column to specify which qualifier ion has been chosenfrom the ms of the target compound. The qualifier ion is used as an indicator that thecorrect target compound has been identified.
Column Comment.25: QUANTIFIER ADDITIVE AMOUNT: This column is used to keep track of the amountof quantifier additive combined with the sample in question. This information isrequired to compare to the data resulting from the analysis of the chromatogram.
Column Comment.28: QUANTIFIER ADDITIVE DESCRIPTION: A narrative description regarding thequantifier additive and any information about the additive.
Column Comment.29: QUANTIFIER ADDITIVE TYPE: The type of quantifier additive (internal standard)that was combined with the sample.
Column Comment.30: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.31: REPORTED INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating that the value from this gaschromatogram was reported as raw data.
Column Comment.32: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.33: STEP SEQUENCE NUMBER: A unique number indicating the sequence of the stepamong other steps in the preparation and processing of the sample. This column is asufficient method to keep track of what is done in the sample analysis. However, ifthe requirement for more complicated tracking such as two steps occurringsimultaneously or if steps are needed to be added to the initial procedure, use thetwo columns STEP_SEQ_NO1 and STEP_SEQ_NO2 in the tableANL_STEP_XREF.
Column Comment.34: SUBSTANCE IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a substance that can be describedeither chemically or in terms of composition. Elements, ions, isotopes, isomers,minerals, chemicals, solvents, production substances, hydrocarbons etc are all listed.Be advised that many applications and agencies may use the same term, but thedefinition and composition details may not be the same. Use the SUBSTANCE XREFtable to capture relationships between substances, such as similar substances.
Column Comment.35: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.36: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.37: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.38: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.39: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.40: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.41: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
